Data.event_text: 4 January  The Foreign Office warns British nationals against all but essential travel to Iran and Iraq, following a US airstrike in Baghdad the previous day in which Iranian general Qasem Soleimani was killed.

links.text: -"Qasem Soleimani: Foreign Office hardens Iran and Iraq travel advice". BBC News. 4 January 2020. Retrieved 5 January 2020.-

Data.event_text: Reynhard Sinaga, described as "the most prolific rapist in British legal history", is sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 30 years, after being found guilty of raping or sexually assaulting 48 men in Manchester. Police believe he may have been responsible for assaulting a total of nearly 200 victims.

links.text: -"Reynhard Sinaga: man jailed for life for raping dozens of men in Manchester". The Guardian. 6 January 2020. Archived from the original on 6 January 2020. Retrieved 6 January 2020.-
-"Reynhard Sinaga: man jailed for life for raping dozens of men in Manchester". The Guardian. 6 January 2020. Archived from the original on 6 January 2020. Retrieved 6 January 2020.-

Data.event_text: Downing Street states that the UK will not support US President Donald Trump's threat to bomb Iranian cultural and heritage sites.

links.text: -"UK would not back US bombing of Iran cultural sites – No 10". The Guardian. 6 January 2020. Retrieved 6 January 2020.-

Data.event_text: 4 February  In London, Prime Minister Boris Johnson, naturalist Sir David Attenborough, and Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte launch the 26th session of the Conference of the Parties (COP26), a major UN climate summit to be held in Glasgow in November 2020 (later postponed to 2021). Johnson announces, subject to consultation, that coal power could be phased out by 2024, a year earlier than previously planned and the phase-out of new petrol and diesel vehicles could be brought forward from 2040 to 2035. He also reaffirms the UK's commitment to reaching net zero carbon by 2050.

links.text: -Yorke, Harry (4 February 2020). "Coal power to be phased out by 2024 as Boris Johnson says UK has duty to fight climate change as first industrialised nation". The Daily Telegraph. Archived from the original on 5 February 2020. Retrieved 5 February 2020.-

Data.event_text: 21 February  COVID-19 in the UK A sample is taken from a 75-year-old woman from Nottinghamshire later identified as the earliest person known to have been infected by SARS-CoV-2 in the UK; the sample tests positive when examined months later in August. She is also probably the first person in the UK to die with COVID-19.

25 February  A landmark study shows that life expectancy in England has stalled for the first time in more than 100 years and that health inequities are growing wider than a decade ago. The study says that this can largely be attributed to the United Kingdom government austerity programme.

Data.event_text: Boris Johnson warns that "tougher measures" may be introduced if people do not follow government advice on social distancing. Empty streets in central London at the end of

In a televised address, Boris Johnson announces a UK-wide lockdown with immediate effect, to contain the spread of the SARS-CoV-2. People can leave their homes only for "very limited purposes"  shopping for basic necessities; for one form of exercise a day; for any medical need; and to travel to and from work when "absolutely necessary". A number of other restrictions are imposed, with police given powers to enforce the measures, including the use of fines.

Data.event_text: Dominic Cummings scandal Durham Constabulary conclude that no offence had been committed by Dominic Cummings in travelling from London to Durham during lockdown. Data.event_text: 13 August  A-level results are published in England, Northern Ireland and Wales. This year's exams were cancelled due to the COVID-19 epidemic, so results were instead calculated using predictions submitted by teachers, called centre assessed grades (CAGs). The predictions were then moderated by the regulator, Ofqual, using an algorithm designed to eliminate grade inflation. This gave an overall pass rate 0.7% higher than in 2019, with more students being accepted for their first choice university course than in that year. Following concerns that 39% of results predicted by teachers in England were downgraded by the moderation process, Ofqual accuses some teachers of submitting "implausibly high" predictions. University data shows that 79% of the 2019 university intake did not achieve their predicted grades in exams.

links.text: -Hazell, Will (13 August 2020). "A-level results 2020: 39% of teacher predicted grades downgraded by algorithm amid calls for U-turn". i.-
-Turner, Camilla; Mikhailova, Anna; Neilan, Catherine (13 August 2020). "Teachers accused of submitting 'implausibly high' predicted grades as A-level results row grows". The Telegraph.-
-Elgot, Jesssica; Adams, Richard (19 August 2020). "Ofqual exam results algorithm was unlawful, says Labour". The Guardian. Retrieved 19 August 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK The new "rule of six" law comes into force. In England, unless one of the exceptions applies, such as team sports, sailing, angling, shooting, polo, dodgeball, floorball and goalball, the law provides authority to limit the number of persons in a gathering to a maximum of six. Equivalent rules also begin in Wales and Scotland, with some differences including exemptions for children under the ages of 11 and 12 respectively.

Data.event_text: Plans for 40 new hospitals by 2030 are confirmed as part of a package worth £3.7 billion, with a further eight planned.

links.text: -"PM confirms £3.7 billion for 40 hospitals in biggest hospital building programme in a generation". GOV.UK. 2 October 2020. Retrieved 4 November 2021.-

Data.event_text: 3 October  The wettest day on record occurs, with an average of 31.7 mm (1.24 in) of rain across the entire country.

links.text: -"Extreme weather: October downpour sees UK's wettest day on record". BBC News. 16 October 2020. Retrieved 16 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: A huge spike in new cases occurs from a backlog of unreported positive results, caused by an IT glitch. This results in the daily figure almost doubling on 3 October, and then nearly doubling again on 4 October.

links.text: -"UK coronavirus cases jump by nearly 23,000 amid infection backlog". The Guardian. 4 October 2020. Retrieved 5 October 2020.-
-"Covid: 16,000 coronavirus cases missed in daily figures after IT error". BBC News. 5 October 2020. Retrieved 5 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: The cumulative total number of COVID-19 cases in the UK exceeds half a million.

links.text: -"UK Covid cases pass half a million as further 22,961 reported in single day due to counting fault". Sky News. 4 October 2020. Retrieved 5 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: 7 October  British Airways' last two Heathrow-based Boeing 747 planes depart from the airport on their final flight.

links.text: -"Final flight for British Airways' last two Heathrow-based Boeing 747 planes". BBC News. 8 October 2020. Retrieved 8 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic in England The ONS reports that SARS-CoV-2 infections in England have "increased rapidly" with one in 240 people infected. Science advisers warn that hospital admissions are now "very close" to levels seen at the start of the crisis in early March.

links.text: -"Covid cases have 'increased rapidly' in England, says ONS". BBC News. 9 October 2020. Retrieved 9 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak announces that workers will get two-thirds of their wages paid for by the government if their employer is forced to shut because of the British government response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

links.text: -"Covid-19: UK workers to get 67% of pay if firms told to shut". BBC News. 9 October 2020. Retrieved 9 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: 11 October  At the 2020 Eifel Grand Prix, Lewis Hamilton equals Michael Schumacher's record of 91 for the most Formula One Grand Prix wins.

links.text: -"Eifel Grand Prix: Lewis Hamilton equals Michael Schumacher record with 91st win". BBC News. 11 October 2020. Retrieved 12 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: 12 October  COVID-19 pandemic in England Boris Johnson tells the Commons there will be a new three-tier alert system for local authorities in England  medium (tier 1), high (tier 2), and very high (tier 3).

links.text: -"Boris Johnson unveils three-tier Covid restrictions for England". The Guardian. 12 October 2020. Retrieved 12 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: 13 October  Unemployment reaches 4.5 per cent, as redundancies are reported to be at their highest level since 2009.

links.text: -"Unemployment rate hits highest level in three years". BBC News. 13 October 2020. Retrieved 13 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: Brexit Boris Johnson contends that trade talks with the EU are effectively "over", and that the UK should "get ready" for arrangements with the EU to be "more like Australia's" from 1 January 2021.

links.text: -"Brexit: Trade talks with the EU are 'over', says No 10". BBC News. 16 October 2020. Retrieved 16 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic in England With SARS-CoV-2 infections in Greater Manchester increasing rapidly, and mayor Andy Burnham refusing to accept further restrictions, Boris Johnson warns he may "need to intervene" if new measures cannot be agreed.

links.text: -"PM warns he may 'need to intervene' on Manchester". BBC News. 16 October 2020. Retrieved 16 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: 20 October  The House of Lords rejects the Internal Market Bill, voting by 395 to 169 (a majority of 226) for a "regret" amendment.

links.text: -"Internal Market Bill: UK Government suffers heavy Lords defeat". The National. 20 October 2020. Retrieved 20 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: 23 October  COVID-19 pandemic in Scotland Nicola Sturgeon confirms that Scotland is to enter a new five-level system of social distancing restrictions.

links.text: -"Covid: Scotland to enter new five-level alert system". BBC News. 23 October 2020. Retrieved 23 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: 25 October  Nave Andromeda incident An oil tanker south-east of the Isle of Wight, suspected to have been hijacked by Nigerian stowaways, is stormed by the Special Boat Service. Seven people believed to be Nigerians seeking British asylum are handed over to Hampshire Police.

links.text: -"Tanker stowaways: 'Hijacking' ends after special forces storm ship". BBC News. 26 October 2020. Retrieved 26 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic in England A major study by Imperial College London suggests that nearly 100,000 people are catching the virus every day in England, a figure now doubling every nine days. The study authors warn that "something has to change" at this "critical stage".

links.text: -"Covid-19: Nearly 100,000 catching virus every day – study". BBC News. 29 October 2020. Retrieved 29 October 2020.-
-"Coronavirus infections rising rapidly in England, REACT study shows". Imperial College London. 29 October 2020. Retrieved 29 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: The Labour Party suspends former leader Jeremy Corbyn over his reaction to a report into anti-semitism.

links.text: -"Corbyn suspended over Labour anti-Semitism report". BBC News. 29 October 2020. Retrieved 29 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic in England In a televised address, PM Boris Johnson announces a new four-week lockdown for England, to be enforced from 5 November until 2 December.

links.text: -"Covid-19: England gets ready for new four-week lockdown". BBC News. 1 November 2020. Retrieved 1 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK The UK exceeds 1 million cases.

links.text: -"Coronavirus: Confirmed COVID-19 cases in the UK surpass one million mark". Sky News. 31 October 2020. Retrieved 31 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: 3 November  The UK terror threat level is raised from "substantial" to "severe", following recent Islamist attacks in France and Austria.

links.text: -"UK terrorism threat level raised to 'severe'". BBC News. 3 November 2020. Retrieved 3 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic in England A second lockdown comes into force in England in attempt to curb rising COVID-19 cases. The lockdown is scheduled to last four weeks.

links.text: -"What are the new lockdown rules in the UK?". The Independent. 5 November 2020. Retrieved 28 December 2022.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak extends the government's furlough scheme to the end of March 2021.

links.text: -"Covid: Rishi Sunak to extend furlough scheme to end of March". BBC News. 5 November 2020. Retrieved 14 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Dominic Chappell, the former owner of BHS, is sentenced to six years in jail for tax evasion.

links.text: -"Former BHS owner jailed for 6 years for tax evasion". BBC News. 5 November 2020. Retrieved 5 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK The Scottish Government and the British Government impose a ban on non-British citizens arriving from Denmark after a new SARS-CoV-2 variant, Cluster 5, being spread from mink to humans in mink farms.

links.text: -"Covid in Scotland: 39 more deaths registered as cases rise". BBC News. 7 November 2020. Retrieved 7 November 2020.-
-"Coronavirus: UK bans Denmark visitors over mink Covid-19 fears". BBC News. 7 November 2020. Retrieved 7 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Boris Johnson congratulates Joe Biden on being elected President of the United States, saying "The US is our most important ally and I look forward to working closely together on our shared priorities, from climate change to trade and security."

links.text: -"Boris Johnson congratulates Joe Biden on US election win". BBC News. 7 November 2020. Retrieved 7 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 9 November  The House of Lords votes by 433 to 165 to remove a section of the Internal Market Bill which allowed the government to break international law.

links.text: -"Brexit: Government's bill suffers heavy House of Lords defeat". BBC News. 9 November 2020. Retrieved 10 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: A record high level of redundancies is reported by the ONS, with about 314,000 people made redundant in the three months to September, more than during the peak of the Great Recession.

links.text: -"UK unemployment rate continues to surge". BBC News. 10 November 2020. Retrieved 10 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Following the first successful phase III trial of a COVID-19 vaccine, Health Secretary Matt Hancock states that the NHS is ready to start providing doses in the UK "as fast as safely possible", with a mass roll-out expected "in the first part of next year".

links.text: -"Covid vaccine: First vaccine offers 90% protection". BBC News. 9 November 2020. Retrieved 9 November 2020.-
-"Covid vaccine: NHS ready for Pfizer roll-out, says Matt Hancock". BBC News. 10 November 2020. Retrieved 10 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 11 November  COVID-19 in the UK The number of deaths from COVID-19 in the UK exceeds 50,000.

links.text: -"Covid: UK first country in Europe to pass 50,000". BBC News. 11 November 2020. Retrieved 11 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 13 November  Lee Cain, director of communications at Downing Street, announces his intention to stand down at the end of the year after reports of infighting in Number 10. Dominic Cummings, Boris Johnson's chief adviser and long-time "ally" to Cain, resigns shortly after.

links.text: -"Lee Cain: Top Boris Johnson aide quits amid infighting at No 10". BBC News. 13 November 2020. Retrieved 14 November 2020.-
-"Dominic Cummings: PM's top adviser leaves No 10 to 'clear the air'". BBC News. 13 November 2020. Retrieved 14 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 14 November  The government commissions research into space-based solar power.

links.text: -"UK government commissions space solar power stations research". UK Government. 14 November 2020. Retrieved 16 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Lewis Hamilton wins a seventh Formula One title, equalling the record of Michael Schumacher.

links.text: -"Lewis Hamilton wins seventh Formula 1 title – equalling Michael Schumacher". BBC News. 15 November 2020. Retrieved 15 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Boris Johnson is told to self-isolate by NHS Test and Trace after meeting MP Lee Anderson, who later tested positive for COVID-19. Downing Street says that the PM does not show any symptoms and will continue working from Number 10 whilst self-isolating.

links.text: -"Boris Johnson self-isolating after MP tests positive for Covid-19". BBC News. 15 November 2020. Retrieved 15 November 2020.-
-"Boris Johnson told to self-isolate after contact with Covid-positive MP". The Guardian. 15 November 2020. Retrieved 15 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 16 November  COVID-19 in the UK The government orders five million doses of a new COVID-19 vaccine by American biotech company Moderna, after a phase III trial shows it to have almost 95% efficacy.

links.text: -"UK orders 5m doses of Moderna vaccine". BBC News. 16 November 2020. Retrieved 16 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Labour readmits Jeremy Corbyn, following his suspension over antisemitism on 29 October. Keir Starmer subsequently decides not to restore Corbyn's party whip.

links.text: -"Jeremy Corbyn: Labour readmits ex-leader after anti-Semitism row". BBC News. 17 November 2020. Retrieved 17 November 2020.-
-"Labour: Bring back 'persecuted' Corbyn, allies demand". BBC News. 18 November 2020. Retrieved 18 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: A plan to ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars from 2040 is brought forward to 2030 under Boris Johnson's 10-point plan to tackle climate change.

links.text: -"New petrol and diesel cars banned from sale after 2030 under government's green plan". Sky News. 18 November 2020. Retrieved 18 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: The government announces an extra £16.5 billion in defence spending over the next four years to "extend British influence".

links.text: -"Defence funding boost 'extends British influence'". BBC News. 19 November 2020. Retrieved 19 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Sources familiar with the Cabinet Office report that an inquiry into allegations of bullying by Home Secretary Priti Patel concluded that she broke the Ministerial Code.

links.text: -"Priti Patel: PM to announce decision on home secretary's future". BBC News. 20 November 2020. Retrieved 20 November 2020.-
-"Bullying inquiry 'found evidence Priti Patel broke ministerial code'". The Guardian. 19 November 2020. Retrieved 20 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: The PlayStation 5 is released in the UK. Delivery problems are reported, due to huge demand.

links.text: -"Sony PlayStation 5 delivery delays spark row over who is to blame". BBC News. 19 November 2020. Retrieved 19 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Sir Alex Allan resigns as the Prime Minister's adviser on the Ministerial Code, after Johnson rejects his findings and expresses "full confidence" in Priti Patel.

links.text: -"Priti Patel backed by Boris Johnson despite bullying report findings". The Guardian. 20 November 2020. Retrieved 20 November 2020.-
-"Priti Patel: Bullying inquiry head quits as PM backs home secretary". BBC News. 20 November 2020. Retrieved 20 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Matt Hancock announces that vaccination centres are being established across the UK in preparation for a SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that, if approved, could begin distribution in December.

links.text: -"Covid-19: UK setting up vaccine centres ready for rollout – Matt Hancock". BBC News. 20 November 2020. Retrieved 21 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 21 November  A Whitehall source reports that Sir Alex Allan had resisted pressure from Boris Johnson to make his findings from the inquiry into Priti Patel more "palatable".

links.text: -"Boris Johnson 'asked for Patel report to be palatable', source claims". BBC News. 21 November 2020. Retrieved 21 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic in England Boris Johnson confirms that the lockdown in England will end on 2 December, with "tougher" three-tiered regional measures being introduced until March 2021.

links.text: -"Covid-19: PM sets out 'tougher' post-lockdown tiers for England". BBC News. 23 November 2020. Retrieved 23 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK AstraZeneca's AZD1222 vaccine, developed in collaboration with the University of Oxford's Jenner Institute and the Oxford Vaccine Group, is shown to be 70% effective in protecting against COVID-19. The efficacy can be raised to 90% if an initial half dose is followed by a full dose a month later, based on interim data.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Oxford University vaccine is highly effective". BBC News. 23 November 2020. Retrieved 23 November 2020.-
-"AZD1222 vaccine met primary efficacy endpoint in preventing COVID-19". AstraZeneca. 23 November 2020. Retrieved 23 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Harry Dunn's parents lose a High Court battle against the Foreign Office over whether their son's alleged killer, Anne Sacoolas, had diplomatic immunity at the time of the road traffic collision in 2019.

links.text: -"Harry Dunn's parents lose High Court immunity review". BBC News. 24 November 2020. Retrieved 24 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK The leaders of the three devolved nations of the UK agree with the prime minister on plans that will permit up to three households to form a "Christmas bubble" during a five-day period from 23 to 27 December, allowing them to mix in homes, places of worship, and outdoor spaces.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Three households can mix over Christmas in UK". BBC News. 24 November 2020. Retrieved 25 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Rishi Sunak says that the "economic emergency" caused by COVID-19 has "only just begun" during his Spending Review announcement to the House of Commons, as figures from the Office for Budget Responsibility show that the economy is forecast to shrink by 11.3% in 2020, the UK's biggest economic decline in 300 years.

links.text: -"Rishi Sunak warns 'economic emergency has only just begun". BBC News. 25 November 2020. Retrieved 25 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: The Duchess of Sussex, Meghan Markle, reveals to The New York Times that she had a miscarriage in July 2020, which caused her "almost unbearable grief".

links.text: -"Duchess of Sussex tells of miscarriage 'pain and grief'". BBC News. 25 November 2020. Retrieved 25 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Baroness Sugg resigns from the Foreign Office, saying it is "fundamentally wrong" to cut the UK overseas aid budget.

links.text: -"Liz Sugg resigns as sustainable development minister over cut to aid spending". The Guardian. 25 November 2020. Retrieved 25 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 26 November  Boris Johnson appoints Dan Rosenfield as his new Downing Street Chief of Staff, effective from 1 January 2021.

links.text: -"Boris Johnson appoints new chief of staff after Cummings exit". BBC News. 26 November 2020. Retrieved 26 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 27 November  COVID-19 in England Following three weeks of lockdown in England, the R number for SARS-CoV-2 in the UK is reported to have fallen to between 0.9 and 1 for the first time since mid-August.

links.text: -"R number for UK below 1 for first time since August". BBC News. 27 November 2020. Retrieved 27 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Retail group Arcadia, whose operations include Topshop, Burton and Dorothy Perkins, goes into administration, threatening 13,000 jobs.

links.text: -"Topshop owner Arcadia goes into administration". BBC News. 30 November 2020. Retrieved 30 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: Protein folding, one of the biggest mysteries in biology, is solved by London-based AI company DeepMind.

links.text: -"One of biology's biggest mysteries 'largely solved' by AI". BBC News. 30 November 2020. Retrieved 30 November 2020.-
-"DeepMind AI cracks 50-year-old problem of protein folding". The Guardian. 30 November 2020. Retrieved 30 November 2020.-
-"AlphaFold: a solution to a 50-year-old grand challenge in biology". DeepMind. 30 November 2020. Retrieved 30 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic in England MPs vote 29178 in favour of introducing England's new COVID-19 tier system with The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (All Tiers) (England) Regulations 2020, with 55 backbench Conservatives voting against the government, while another 16 abstain.

links.text: -"Covid tiers: MPs back tougher system for England, despite Tory rebellion". BBC. 1 December 2020. Retrieved 1 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Debenhams stores are set to close with the loss of 12,000 jobs after attempts to find a buyer for the retailer fell through when JD Sports pulled out.

links.text: -"Debenhams set to close putting 12,000 jobs at risk". BBC. 1 December 2020. Retrieved 1 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 2 December  COVID-19 in the UK The UK becomes the first country to approve the new Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. 800,000 doses are planned for arrival in the coming days, with a further 40 million in 2021, enough to vaccinate 20 million people. The BBC reports that the jab is "the fastest vaccine to go from concept to reality, taking only 10 months to follow the same steps that normally span 10 years."

links.text: -"Covid-19: Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine judged safe for use in UK from next week". BBC. 2 December 2020. Retrieved 2 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Four people are killed after a large explosion at a waste water treatment works in Avonmouth, Bristol.

links.text: -"Avonmouth explosion: Four dead in Bristol water works blast". BBC. 3 December 2020. Retrieved 3 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: The first batch of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine arrives in the UK, and is stored at an undisclosed location ready for distribution to hospitals and vaccination centres around the country.

links.text: -"Covid: First batch of vaccines arrives in the UK". BBC. 3 December 2020. Retrieved 3 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 4 December  Mayor of Liverpool Joe Anderson is arrested, along with four others, on suspicion of conspiracy to commit bribery and witness intimidation, related to the awarding of building contracts in the city.

links.text: -"Liverpool Mayor Joe Anderson arrested in bribery probe". BBC. 4 December 2020. Retrieved 5 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 7 December  MPs vote by 357 to 268, a majority of 89, to reinstate controversial sections of the Internal Market Bill linked to the Northern Ireland protocol, which the EU continues to oppose.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPs reinsert controversial sections of Internal Market Bill". BBC. 7 December 2020. Retrieved 8 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK A 90-year-old British woman, Margaret Keenan, becomes the first person in the world to receive the Pfizer/BioNTech COVID-19 jab as part of a mass vaccination programme. The injection of BNT162b2 is the first of 800,000 doses to be offered to people in the UK, with millions more expected to be ready by 31 December.

links.text: -"Covid-19 vaccine: First person receives Pfizer jab in UK". BBC. 8 December 2020. Retrieved 8 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: A group of former rugby players including Rugby World Cup winner Steve Thompson begin a claim against the game's authorities after being diagnosed with early signs of dementia, saying that repeated blows to the head from playing the sport are to blame.

links.text: -McLaughlin, Chris (8 December 2020). "Steve Thompson in group of ex-rugby union internationals to sue for brain damage". BBC Sport. Retrieved 11 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 12 December  Silverstone Circuit announces the renaming of the "International Pits Straight" the "Lewis Hamilton Straight" after he won his seventh world title and broke the record for most wins.

links.text: -Benson, Andrew (12 December 2020). "Lewis Hamilton: Silverstone renames pit straight after British seven-time champion". BBC Sport. Retrieved 12 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Health Secretary Matt Hancock tells MPs that a new variant of COVID-19, the Alpha variant, has been identified that is spreading faster in some areas of the country. The variant shows changes to the spike protein which could make the virus more infectious.

links.text: -"'New variant' of coronavirus identified in England". BBC News. 14 December 2020. Retrieved 17 December 2020.-
-"New SARS-CoV-2 Variant Spreading Rapidly Through in UK". The Scientist. 16 December 2020. Retrieved 17 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Singer Jesy Nelson leaves the band Little Mix, saying that being in the group had taken a toll on her mental health and that she found the pressure of being in a girl group and living up to expectations very difficult.

links.text: -"Jesy Nelson leaves Little Mix: 'The constant pressure is very hard'". BBC News. 14 December 2020. Retrieved 14 December 2020.-
-Beaumont-Thomas, Ben (14 December 2020). "Jesy Nelson leaves Little Mix to focus on mental health". The Guardian. Retrieved 15 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Criteria on blood donations will focus on individual behaviours instead, and lift a ban on men who have sex with men in the last three months from donating blood. The changes will take effect in summer 2021.

links.text: -"Landmark change to blood donation criteria". Gov.UK. 14 December 2020. Retrieved 7 December 2021.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK London is one of several areas in the South East of England placed into tier 3 of the country's COVID-19 tier system, following a sharp rise of infections in the capital.

links.text: -"Covid: London to move into tier 3 as infections rise". BBC News. 14 December 2020. Retrieved 17 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: The Supreme Court overrules the Court of Appeal ban on the development of a third runway at Heathrow Airport, allowing a planning application to go ahead.

links.text: -"Heathrow wins court battle to build third runway". BBC News. 16 December 2020. Retrieved 17 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 18 December  COVID-19 in the UK The New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Group and the government are informed of evidence of increased transmissibility of the SARS-CoV-2 Alpha variant.

COVID-19 pandemic in England Boris Johnson announces a new 'tier 4' lockdown for London and much of South East England from midnight, as the Alpha variant is identified with a 70% higher transmission rate.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Christmas rules tightened for England, Scotland and Wales". BBC News. 19 December 2020. Retrieved 19 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic in Scotland Nicola Sturgeon announces "firm preventative action"  a ban on travel to the rest of the UK over the festive period; the relaxation of rules on meeting households indoors to only apply on Christmas Day; all of mainland Scotland moving into the toughest level four from 26 December; and schools returning later than originally planned after the Christmas holidays.

links.text: -"Covid: Lockdown looms as Scotland tightens Christmas rules". BBC News. 19 November 2020. Retrieved 19 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy and the Netherlands announce the banning of flights from the UK, in response to SARS-CoV-2 Alpha variant.

links.text: -"Covid: Nations impose UK travel bans over new variant". BBC News. 20 December 2020. Retrieved 20 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: A new record high daily case figure is reported, with 35,928 new infections, double the number of the previous Sunday.

links.text: -"Covid: Cases rise as Christmas rules come into force". BBC News. 20 December 2020. Retrieved 20 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: France announces it will stop freight lorry movements from the UK for 48 hours because of the spread of SARS-CoV-2 Alpha variant in the UK.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Dover port halts exports to France for 48 hours". BBC News. 20 December 2020. Retrieved 20 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 21 December  COVID-19 in the UK The number of countries halting travel from the UK exceeds 40.

links.text: -"Covid-19: More than 40 countries ban UK arrivals". BBC News. 21 December 2020. Retrieved 21 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: The UK and France reach an agreement to reopen their border the following day, allowing freight drivers and EU citizens to travel between the two countries, subject to a recent negative COVID-19 test.

links.text: -"Covid-19: French agree to ease virus travel ban". BBC News. 22 December 2020. Retrieved 29 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Tesco reintroduces a purchasing limit on some items, including eggs, rice, soap and toilet rolls to ensure there is not a shortage of products due to panic buying.

links.text: -"Tesco puts buying caps on several products". BBC News. 22 December 2020. Retrieved 29 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: A new mineral, dark green in colour and named kernowite, is discovered in Cornwall.

links.text: -"Kernowite: New mineral found on rock mined in Cornwall". BBC News. 23 December 2020. Retrieved 23 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: A new highly infectious strain, originating from South Africa, is confirmed to be present in London and the North West of England.
Another record high daily case figure is reported, with 39,237 new infections.

links.text: -"Britain reports record 39,237 new COVID-19 infections, 744 deaths". Reuters. 23 December 2020. Retrieved 23 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 pandemic in England Tier 4 restrictions are announced for more areas in England from Boxing Day.
COVID-19 in the UK The government suspends travel from South Africa.

links.text: -"Covid-19: UK bans travel from South Africa over variant". BBC News. 24 December 2020. Retrieved 24 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Brexit The UK and the European Union agree to a free trade agreement prior to the end of the transition period.

links.text: -"UK and EU agree post-Brexit trade deal". BBC News. 24 December 2020. Retrieved 24 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK The United States becomes the latest country to impose travel restrictions on the UK in response to SARS-CoV-2 Alpha variant, forcing all passengers travelling to the US to produce a negative COVID-19 test before being allowed to travel.

links.text: -"United States bans travellers from UK without a negative coronavirus test". London Evening Standard. 25 December 2020. Retrieved 29 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Following her traditional address to the nation, Channel 4 airs a deepfake video of the Queen's speech, to offer "a stark warning about the advanced technology that is enabling the proliferation of misinformation and fake news in a digital age."

links.text: -"'Deepfake' Queen delivers alternative Christmas speech, in warning about misinformation". CNN. 25 December 2020. Retrieved 26 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: YouTube star LadBaby becomes only the third act in UK chart history to achieve three consecutive Christmas number one singles with his novelty version of Journey's "Don't Stop Believin'".

links.text: -"LadBaby bags third straight Christmas number one". BBC. 25 December 2020. Retrieved 26 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 26 December  Bryony Frost becomes the first female jockey to win the King George VI Chase at Kempton Park.

links.text: -"Frost rides to historic King George win". BBC Sport. Retrieved 26 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Another record high daily case figure is reported, with 41,385 new infections.

links.text: -"COVID-19: UK records 41,385 new coronavirus cases and 357 more deaths". Sky News. 28 December 2020. Retrieved 29 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: The number of patients with the virus in hospitals exceeds 20,000, surpassing the peak of the first wave in April.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Health workers 'back in eye of storm', says NHS chief". BBC News. 29 December 2020. Retrieved 29 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 29 December  COVID-19 in the UK Another record high daily case figure is reported, with 53,135 new infections.

links.text: -"Covid: UK surge in cases an 'extreme concern'". BBC News. 29 December 2020. Retrieved 29 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK The UK approves its second vaccine against COVID-19, developed by Oxford-AstraZeneca, with the first doses due to be given on 4 .

links.text: -"Covid-19: Oxford-AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine approved for use in UK". BBC News. 30 December 2020. Retrieved 30 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: Brexit The post-Brexit trade agreement with the EU is passed in the House of Commons by 521 votes to 73, a majority of 448.

links.text: -"Brexit: MPs overwhelmingly back post-Brexit deal with EU". BBC News. 30 December 2020. Retrieved 30 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Another record high daily case figure is reported, with 55,892 new infections.

links.text: -"Covid-19: UK reports a record 55,892 daily cases". BBC News. 31 December 2020. Retrieved 31 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: The government approves planning consent for the 2.4 GW Hornsea Project Three wind farm. Concerns are raised over the impact on bird colonies in the region.

links.text: -"Hornsea Project Three Offshore Wind Farm given development consent". UK Government. 31 December 2020. Retrieved 2 January 2021.-
-"Bird charity warns of harm from new wind farm". BBC News. 2 January 2021. Retrieved 2 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Brexit The transition period expires at 2300 GMT as the UK completes its final separation from the EU, four and a half years after the referendum.

links.text: -"Brexit: New era for UK as it completes separation from European Union". BBC News. 31 December 2020. Retrieved 31 December 2020.-
-"Brexit: in crisis, without fanfare, UK finally ends the EU era". The Guardian. 31 December 2020. Retrieved 31 December 2020.-
